title: 108_s1814
content: The curr_chunk is a section titled "PURPOSES AND DEFINITIONS." The Act aims to transfer jurisdiction of certain Federal lands in Missouri to the Secretary of Agriculture for the continued operation of the Mingo Job Corps Civilian Conservation Center. It also clarifies that the Secretary of Labor's role regarding the Job Corps Center will not change. Definitions include the Center being located in Stoddard County, Missouri, and an eligible employee being a current Federal Government employee at the Center. The Conservation Center in Missouri is supported by fully funded Washington Office Job Corps staff. Environmental Authorities refer to various laws related to human health and the environment. The National Environmental Policy Act of 1969, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Forest Service, Job Corps, National Forest System, and National Wildlife Refuge System are defined terms related to environmental authorities and conservation efforts. The National Wildlife Refuge System is defined at title 16, United States Code, section 668dd. TRANSFER OF ADMINISTRATION. Transfer of administrative jurisdiction over the Mingo Job Corps Civilian Conservation Center in Stoddard County, Missouri from the Secretary of the Interior to the Secretary of Agriculture is hereby transferred without consideration. Maps and legal descriptions will be available for public inspection, and a legal description and map will be filed within 180 days. The Secretary of Agriculture will transfer administrative jurisdiction over the Mingo Job Corps Civilian Conservation Center in Missouri to the Secretary of Agriculture. The Center will be subject to laws and regulations applicable to the National Forest System, with the Secretary of the Interior allowed to make typographical corrections as needed. The transfer of administrative jurisdiction over the Mingo Job Corps Civilian Conservation Center in Missouri to the Secretary of Agriculture will be implemented. The Secretary of Agriculture shall notify the Secretary of the Interior if the Job Corps Center is no longer used for its purpose, allowing the Secretary of the Interior 180 days to decide on reassuming jurisdiction over the lands. Reversion will be executed through a Letter of Transfer without Congress involvement, with notice published in the Federal Register. Any permits granted by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service on the Center will remain in effect. The Forest Service will continue permits issued by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service on the Center. The Forest Service can reissue or terminate permits under its own terms. It can also exercise all rights of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, including amending, modifying, and revoking permits. The Forest Service is authorized to take over contracts of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service on the Center. The Forest Service will assume obligations of U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service contracts on the Center. Any contract disputes prior to enactment of this Act will be handled by U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. A memorandum of agreement can be entered into for the transfer of employees. The Forest Service will take over obligations from the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, including property transfer, records access, road maintenance, and other issues. The Forest Service will also handle agreements with the Secretary of Labor and have access to all management records of the Center. The Forest Service will take over personnel records, land title records, and personal property from the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service as part of the transfer process. The Forest Service will dispose of property from the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service according to specified procedures. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service will provide an inventory of all property at the Center within 60 days. Property includes buildings, office supplies, vehicles, and equipment. The Forest Service may exclude movable property from transfer if the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service shows that it is necessary for their mission, cannot be replaced cost-effectively, and is not needed for Center management. SEC. 4. COMPLIANCE WITH ENVIRONMENTAL AUTHORITIES. Within 60 days of enactment, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service must provide documentation on the environmental condition of the land to the Forest Service and the Office of Job Corps. Additional information must be shared as it becomes available. Within 120 days, an assessment of the Center's environmental condition must be provided by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service will assess the environmental condition of the Center and provide documentation to the Forest Service and the Office of Job Corps. If action is needed, a memorandum of agreement will be created for the required actions to be taken by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service will provide documentation to the Forest Service and the Office of Job Corps regarding actions taken to protect human health and the environment at the Center. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service will have access to the Center as needed to fulfill their responsibilities under environmental authorities. The Forest Service will not be liable for any activities related to the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service or the Department of Labor at the Center before the enactment of this Act. The Act does not affect liabilities for response actions under environmental laws related to the Center, including costs, penalties, fines, or actions for noncompliance with environmental regulations. The Act does not change responsibilities or liabilities under Environmental Authorities for the Forest Service. Federal agencies responsible for violations at the Center must cover costs for corrective actions and remediation. SEC. 5. PERSONNEL. The Forest Service will accept eligible employees from the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service at their current pay and grade levels without competition. Transferred employees will retain all benefits without interruption, including retirement benefits. Transferred employees from the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service will retain all benefits without interruption, including retirement, TSP, FEHB, FEGLI, leave, and other employee benefits. They will keep their status with CSRS or FERS, carry over accumulated leave time, maintain competitive employment status and tenure, and keep their GM, GS, or WG grade level and pay. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service and the Forest Service will cover their own implementation costs for this Act. Appropriations will be made as necessary to carry out the Act.
